awd_titl_txt: A Support Ecosystem to Expand Capabilities and Opportunities for STEM Undergraduates Following Hurricane Maria
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program supports the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need.  This S-STEM project at the University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez will support 26 scholars in the College of Engineering and the College of Arts and Sciences for three academic years (2018-2021), totaling 78 annual scholarships of $5,000 over the project duration. The proposal seeks to address some of the challenges facing undergraduate STEM students in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria.  The project will enhance and provide students with (1) financial support, (2) academic support, and (3) socio-emotional support to increase retention and graduation.  In addition, the project team will generate important knowledge about student resilience and persistence after a natural disaster, the importance of an ecosystem of support that includes academic and socio-emotional support systems, and the validity of the adage that financial aid alone cannot increase student success.  
 
The goals of the project are: (1) to provide academically talented low-income undergraduate STEM students with  financial, academic, and socio-emotional support; (2) to adapt and implement an ecosystem of proven financial, academic, and socio-emotional support strategies and to study their effects on retention, graduation, and success; and (3) to contribute to the implementation and sustainability of effective evidence-based curricular activities for low-income STEM students.  A quantitative factor analytic study will examine the contributions of the three types of support (financial, academic, socio-emotional) separately and their synergistic effects on student success, retention, and graduation.  A critical outcome of the effort will be insight into the effects of natural disaster on undergraduate students' pursuit of STEM degrees and the importance of a systemic approach to facilitating student success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

EECOS Outcomes Final Report 2022

NSF project Ecosystem to Expand Capabilities and Opportunities to STEM-Scholars (EECOs) increased retention and persistence of STEM-Scholars severely impacted by two major catastrophic events: 1) Hurricane Maria (category four hurricane) in September 2017 devastated the island, with an estimated cost of at least $94.4 billion in damages. 2) On January 7, 2020, a 6.4 magnitude earthquake and a chain of replicas struck the southwest of Puerto Rico. The damage to government structures was calculated in the hundreds of millions, and financial losses were estimated at $3.1 billion. Both events left many students on the brink of abandoning their careers and with high levels of emotional distress. It was the first time a project used financial, academic, and socio-emotional support to assist a STEM- Scholar population severely distressed by natural disasters in Puerto Rico, Figure 1.

The ecosystem had three components: 1) Financial Support granted them scholarships of $2,500 per semester for a maximum of three years. Figure 2 shows the number of STEM-Student's distribution of scholarships among programs. 2) Academic Support addressed scholars' core educational needs, and familiarized them with opportunities for research, graduate school, and STEM jobs. Faculty mentors regularly conversed with their respective scholars about academic progress in general and the STEM discipline. Mentors advised scholars concerning course selection for the subsequent semesters to ensure appropriate progress toward degree completion. Provided the student's reflections on the importance of keeping a reasonable pace on academic load to keep or improve GPA and motivated the student to acquire research experience. Also, mentors referred scholars to existing campus services to address individual academic needs and the appropriate campus office to address socio-emotional needs. Mentors prepared and submitted reports on each of their scholar?s academic progress, seminar or conference attendance, work, and study plans, and developing interests. The reports were digitized for project use on the CiViCRM platform. 3) Socio-emotional Support comprised three modules: a) personal development activities, b) referrals to psychological counseling services, and c) Moodle online forum. These modules adapted and implemented an intervention methodology to foster a growth mindset for research to develop resilience (grit) and learning growth mindset among scholars to help them persist in their STEM education and career goals.

Major outcomes:

  • Sixty-five STEM-Scholars (62 undergraduate and 5 graduate) on the verge of withdrawal from the university could continue their careers with the help of financial support. Forty-nine students of the 65 STEM Scholars graduated last summer (July 2022).
  • Two undergraduates in the program were able to receive support during the first year of the graduate program transition.  
  • 65 STEM-Scholars had the opportunity to receive emotional support. Among these Scholars, 38 (59%) were unique referrals to counseling because of emotional distress, and 7 continued to receive psychological treatment for chronic conditions after the program ended. A decrease in the need for psychological services was observed during the last year compared to the previous two years.
  • 65 STEM-Scholars received academic support through mentoring, most of whom enrolled in research experiences.
  • 65 STEM-Scholars were invited and assisted to seminars on different subjects, the socio-emotional component, and in their academic field.
  • 65 STEM-Scholars received advice during enrolment to see what courses they register in and thus complete their academic program.
  • 65-STEM were exposed to belong to this Project, which undoubtedly taught strategies to overcome difficult moments and opened a broader vision of participation in activities that have a positive impact on their education.
  • Four virtual conferences, 2 posters, and two publications were presented in venues.
  • A video documentary showing 6 successful EECOS alums from the first two years was created, 4 victims of Hurricane Maria and 2 victims of earthquakes. The alumni tell their stories of overcoming the traumas of having lost everything and how the ecosystem of help provided by the EECOS program was instrumental in helping them graduate and achieve their academic dreams without giving up. Figure 3 contains the link to the documentary.

The External Evaluator recognizes the hard work and efforts made by each member of the Project to attain all goals and objectives established, considering the enormous challenges presented by unprecedented events, earthquakes, and a pandemic.  EECOS demonstrated to be a Project that must be replicated elsewhere. On the other hand, the students expressed immense gratitude towards this project, which made their dream of continuing to study possible.

Personnel of project EECOs acknowledge the collaboration of the Financial, Services, the Department of Counseling and Psychological Services, the Office of Planning, Research, and Institutional improvement (OPIMI) at UPR, Mayaguez Campus, who helped in all the processes so that the objectives of this project were achieved.
